awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Research in Physics and Astronomy at UC Santa Barbara
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates site in Physics at the University of California-Santa Barbara.  The site will support eight students per year for nine weeks of summer research in topics including Astronomy/Astrophysics, Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics, Biophysics/Physics of Living Systems, Condensed Matter Physics, Gravity, and Elementary Particle Physics.  The REU is intended to be a transformative experience in the career path of the participants, particularly those from institutions with fewer research opportunities, by providing the necessary mentorship to explore their interest in Physics and develop the professional skills needed to succeed in a career in academia or industry.

The project will develop research and professional skills of the next generation of academic physicists and the STEM workforce by giving undergraduates the opportunity to participate in cutting edge research, with faculty who have extensive experience in fostering undergraduate research from Freshman to Senior level students. The REU students will engage in research to explore black hole entropy, search for new Physics at the Large Hadron Collider, study the dynamics of morphogenesis, tackle the Physics of accretion disks, perform quantum simulation using ultracold quantum gases, or discover exoplanets, contributing to the creation and advancement of knowledge in a broad variety of research areas, at the same time learning the skills that transfer to a variety of STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
During the 4 summers from 2020 through 2023, 27 students participated in the first cycle of the newly established UCSB Physics REU program. Of these participants, 52% were from small colleges, 59% were female students and 22% were underrepresented minority students. As of writing this report, 21 out of these 27 students have since been accepted into Ph.D programs in Physics or related fields, 2 have jobs in STEM fields, and 4 others still have a year or two to complete their Bachelor's degrees.

The intellectual merit consisted of the REU students conducting individual research for 9 weeks in the summer under the guidance of faculty mentors in frontier areas spanning neutrino physics, ultracold atoms, Josephson junctions, morphogenesis, exoplanets and quantum gravity, to name a few. The deliverables at the end of the program included a Physics journal style paper report on their project, and presenting their work by giving a talk at the REU Symposium. With support and encouragement from the program, students also went on to present their REU work at professional conferences including at the American Physical Society, and American Astronomical Society meetings.

In addition to research, the students participated in a program of professional development activities preparing them for a career in physics or closely related fields. These included workshops and training for scientific writing and presentations, workshops and individual mentoring on graduate school and fellowship applications, and opportunities to learn about careers in Industry and National Labs via panel presentations.

The broader impact of the program derives from recruiting and mentoring a diverse group of students and providing them a transformative experience consisting of cutting-edge research, professional development and community-building opportunities which helps prepare them for a career in STEM.


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Sathya Guruswamy
